  physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang. On the left
 there is a panel consisting of rows of interlocking triangles containing floral designs and tiny rosettes. The body of the kain panjang features birds perched on flowering lotus branches. There are no signatures seen on this kain panjang.

  subject_terms_1: Peranakan birds (motifs) flower (motif) foliage (motif)

  subject_terms_3: Peranakan costumes Batik

  sgcool_label_text: Rows of interlocking triangles (or tumpal) containing floral designs and tiny rosettes are shown the broad
 vertical panel of this batik (or kepala).  On the ‘body’ or main design field of this kain panjang
 birds with elaborate plumage perch on flowering lotus branches.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Soen King (1861-1942)
 the first in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  Her batiks feature the classic layout typical of her time
 and are embellished with Chinese traditional motifs.  These motifs include lotus flowers
 centipedes and cloud motifs
 which are rendered sensitively and imaginatively.  The combination of natural red and blue dyes on a cream ground is also characteristic of batiks made during this period in the north coast of Java
 before the invention and widespread popularity of chemical dyes in batik sarongs by the late 19th century.  Oey Soen King’s pieces were all unsigned as signatures were not yet fashionable.

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang. On the left, there is a panel consisting of rows of interlocking triangles containing floral designs and tiny rosettes. The body of the kain panjang features birds perched on flowering lotus branches. There are no signatures seen on this kain panjang.
metadata.subject_terms_2: Motifs Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people) Batik
metadata.sgcool_label_text: Rows of interlocking triangles (or tumpal) containing floral designs and tiny rosettes are shown the broad, vertical panel of this batik (or kepala).  On the ‘body’ or main design field of this kain panjang, birds with elaborate plumage perch on flowering lotus branches.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Soen King (1861-1942), the first in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  Her batiks feature the classic layout typical of her time, and are embellished with Chinese traditional motifs.  These motifs include lotus flowers, centipedes and cloud motifs, which are rendered sensitively and imaginatively.  The combination of natural red and blue dyes on a cream ground is also characteristic of batiks made during this period in the north coast of Java, before the invention and widespread popularity of chemical dyes in batik sarongs by the late 19th century.  Oey Soen King’s pieces were all unsigned as signatures were not yet fashionable.
